author: Martin Bell
title: Ski reviews: expert all mountain skis
text:
£650 including bindings Best for: Arcing across firm snow 
One of the best in this category for long turns and clear winner for high speed, the RTM 84s are at their happiest laying down solid GS turns on hard snow – they're grippy, supportive and super-stable. Two pieces of Völkl technology contribute: the UVO (Ultimate Vibration Object), which sits on the topsheet and takes care of dampening, and the 3D.Ridge, running up the centre of the ski, providing precise power transmission. While they prefer hard snow, they're also fairly versatile, offering a decent platform for big turns off piste. Like many of these "mid-fat" skis, their short turns aren't quite as strong as their long ones. Tech talk 
Sidewall construction, with a wood core that is strengthened with steel. Tip and tail rockers. 
+ Edge hold, long turns, high speed, smoothness, groomed piste – None 
Lengths: 162, 167, 172, 177, 182 Sidecut: 131/84/112 (all lengths) Radius: 17.9m (177) Women's all mountain expert 
All mountain skis are, by definition, intended to be equally versatile on or off piste. To achieve this, most of them have medium waist widths, falling mainly into the 85–100 mm range. Atomic Vantage 90 CTI W 
£480 Best for: Aspiring freeriders 
Strong, stable skis, these Vantages are fun in soft snow, cutting through crud and floating through powder. On piste, they grip well, and have no obvious weaknesses, although do not score as highly as many of their rivals – apart, that is, from in moguls, where they are best of this. They would be well suited to someone looking to make their first forays into freeride terrain. Tech talk 
Partial cap construction with full sidewalls underfoot. Poplar wood core, strengthened with titanium and a woven carbon mesh. Fifteen per cent tip and 10 per cent tail rockers. 
+ Off piste, moguls
